section.title: Unit Tests
section.para: OTRS provides unit tests for core modules.

section.title: Creating a test file
section.para: The test files are stored in .t files under /scripts/test/*.t. For example the file /scripts/test/Calendar.t for the Calendar Module.

section.title: Prerequisites for testing
section.para: To be able to run the unit tests, you need to have all optional Perl modules installed, except those for different database backends than what you are using. Run bin/otrs.CheckModules.pl to verify your module installation.

You also need to have an instance of the OTRS web frontend running on the FQDN that is configured in your local OTRS's Config.pm file. This OTRS instance must use the same database that is configured for the unit tests.

section.title: Testing
section.para:
To check your tests, just use bin/otrs.Console.pl Dev::UnitTest::Run --test Calendar to use /scripts/test/Calendar.t.
shell:/opt/otrs> bin/otrs.Console.pl Dev::UnitTest::Run --test Calendar +-------------------------------------------------------------------+ /opt/otrs/scripts/test/Calendar.t: +-------------------------------------------------------------------+ ok 1 - EventAdd() ===================================================================== Product: OTRS 5.0.x git Test Time: 0 s Time: 2010-04-02 12:58:37 Host: yourhost.example.com Perl: 5.8.9 OS: linux TestOk: 1 TestNotOk: 0 ===================================================================== shell:/opt/otrs>

section.title: UnitTest API
section.para:
OTRS provides a small and simple API for unit testing that was used in the previous example. Here we'll list the most important functions, please also see the online API reference of
Kernel::System::UnitTest .

section.title: True()
False()
Is()
IsNot()
IsDeeply()
section.para:
This function compares complex data structures for equality. $A and $B have to be references.
$Self->IsDeeply( $A, $B, 'Test Name', );

section.title: IsNotDeeply()
section.para:
This function compares complex data structures for inequality. $A and $B have to be references.
$Self->IsNotDeeply( $A, $B, 'Test Name', );
